resources.string: The Villa features recurring shapes, such as the diamond and the eight-pointed star. The ceiling beams are original and made of cypress. The construction materials were all bought locally. The entire Villa was bought by the Quincy Park District in 1955 and had to be restored in 1975 before re-opening in 1976.

The Villa was built in 1900 by William "George" Metz, for a cost of $7,000. The Courtyard is a gallery supported by Byzantine-styled arches. It rests on eight Islamic Pillars. The Villa is the only Islamic-influenced architecture in Quincy. In the center is the reflecting pool. The whole room is designed to mimic a Mid-Eastern pattern.

Lavish parties were often held at the Villa, often with people sitting around the reflecting pool. The China cabinet and the buffet are original. The nickel-plated brass on the cabinet is also original.

Also called the "Smoking Room", this room features a particularly beautiful view of the Mississippi. Under the window there used to be an alabaster fireplace fa√ßade. Architect George Behrensmeyer drew the blueprint for the Villa.

The Villas walls are twelve to eighteen inch thick brick, covered by one half to one inch think plaster. There is a fireplace in every (original) bedroom. Also, all of the rooms open into the Courtyard. William"George" Metz was said to have a dog named "Bingo".
